title: Researchers study plastic pollution in Great Lakes | RIT
body: In their study, Hoffman and co-author Eric Hittinger, assistant professor of public policy at RIT, report that half of the plastic pollution entering the Great Lakes—5,000 metrics tons per year—goes into Lake Michigan, followed by Lake Erie with 2,500 metric tons and Lake Ontario with 1,400 metric tons.
readable_content: - Ashley (2023-12-08): Thank you for sharing this piece of information about the study on plastic pollution in the Great Lakes. This issue is quite concerning, and it's crucial to have a comprehensive understanding of the scale of the problem. The findings of the study are certainly eye-opening, especially the estimated amount of plastic debris entering the Great Lakes from the United States and Canada every year. It's essential to raise awareness and work towards effective cleanup efforts and pollution prevention strategies.
